{{Taxobox | image = Anopheles claviger adult John Curtis British Entomology 210.png | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Arthropod]]a | classis = [[Insect]]a | ordo = [[Diptera]] | familia = [[Culicidae]] | subfamilia = [[Anophelinae]] | genus = ''[[Anopheles]]'' | species = '''''A. claviger''''' | binomial = ''Anopheles claviger'' | binomial_authority = ([[Johann Wilhelm Meigen|Meigen]], 1804) }}
'''''Anopheles claviger''''' is a [[mosquito]] species found in [[Palearctic ecozone]] covering [[Europe]], [[North Africa]], northern [[Arabian Peninsula]], and northern [[Asia]]. It is responsible for transmitting [[malaria]] in some of these regions.<ref name=kaiser>{{cite book|last=Kaiser|first=Norbert Becker, Dusan Petric, Marija Zgomba, Clive Boase, Minoo Madon, Christine Dahl, Achim|title=Mosquitoes and Their Control|year=2010|publisher=Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg|location=Berlin, Heidelberg|isbn=978-3-540-92874-4|pages=166–168|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JIfgVr1f4IQC&pg|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Muir|first=D.A.|author2=Keilany, M.|title=''Anopheles claviger'' meigen as a malaria vector in Syria|work=WHO Technical Documents|year=1972|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/65623/1/WHO_MAL_72.757.pdf?ua=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Knio|first=K.M.|author2=Markarian, N. |author3=Kassis, A. |author4= Nuwayri-Salti, N. |title=A two-year survey on mosquitoes of Lebanon|journal=Parasite|year=2005|volume=12|issue=3|pages=229–235|doi=10.1051/parasite/2005123229}} {{open access}}</ref> The mosquito is made up of a species complex consisting of ''An. claviger [[sensu stricto]]'' and ''An. petragnani'' Del Vecchio. ''An. petragnani'' is found only in western [[Mediterranean region]], and is reported to bite only animals, hence, it is not involved in human malaria.
It was on ''An. claviger'' that [[Giovanni Battista Grassi]] established the fact that only the female mosquitoes are responsible for transmitting malarial parasite ''[[Plasmodium falciparum]]'' in humans.<ref name=capanna>{{cite journal|last=Capanna|first=E|title=Battista Grassi entomologist and the Roman School of Malariology|journal=Parassitologia|year=2008|volume=50|issue=3-4|pages=201–11|pmid=20055229}}</ref>
''An. claviger'' was known for breeding abundantly in the [[Åland Islands]] of Finland. As a result, [[malaria]] was endemic in the islands for at least 150 years, with severe malaria outbreaks being recorded in the 17th century, and in 1853 and 1862.<ref name=protheropagew>{{cite book|last=Prothero | first=G.W.| authorlink = George Walter Prothero | title=The Åland Islands | date=1920 | publisher=Great Britain. Foreign Office. Historical Section | page= 3 | url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/9147/view/1/15/}}</ref>
==Scientific name==
''Anopheles claviger'' was first described by [[Johann Wilhelm Meigen]] in 1804. However due to its close resemblance with other anopheline mosquitoes, the systematics was variously changed. Originally Meigen named it ''Culex claviger'' which he changed it to ''An. bifurcutus'' in 1818. This was for a long period the accepted [[Binomial nomenclature|binomial]] but soon they realised that [[Carl Linnaeus]] had already used the name for the males of ''[[Culex pipiens]]''.<ref name=kaiser/> After a decade [[James Francis Stephens]] renamed it ''An. grisescens'' in 1828. A number of scientific names was introduced after they were discovered from one region after another. Some recognised synonyms are:<ref name="WRBU">{{cite web|title=Anopheles claviger |url=http://www.wrbu.org/SpeciesPages_ANO/ANO_A-hab/ANcla_hab.html |publisher=he Walter Reed Biosystematics Unit |accessdate=26 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426232356/http://www.wrbu.org/SpeciesPages_ANO/ANO_A-hab/ANcla_hab.html |archivedate=26 April 2014 }}</ref> * ''An. amaurus'' Martini * ''An. grisescens'' Stephens * ''An. habibi'' Mulligan and Puri * ''An. missiroli'' Del Vecchio * ''An. pollutus'' Canamares * ''An. turkestani'' Shingarev * ''An. villosus'' Robineau-Desvoidy
Italian biologists G. Del Vecchio in 1939 and G. Lupascu in 1941 were the first to notice that ''An. claviger'' comprised two morphologically distinct species. In 1962 M. Coluzzi revised the taxonomic status by classifying ''An. claviger'' as a species complex inclusive of ''An. petragnani''. The species could be identified only on small structural variation in the pupal stages,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Zamburlini|first=R|title=Classification of ''Anopheles claviger'' (Diptera, Culicidae) in north-eastern Italy|journal=Parassitologia|year=1998 |language=Italian|volume=40|issue=3|pages=347–51|pmid=10376296}}</ref> but is now identified using biochemical and molecular tools.<ref name=kampen>{{cite journal|last=Kampen|first=H|author2=Sternberg, A |author3=Proft, J |author4=Bastian, S |author5=Schaffner, F |author6=Maier, WA |author7= Seitz, HM |title=Polymerase chain reaction-based differentiation of the mosquito sibling species Anopheles claviger s.s. and Anopheles petragnani (Diptera: Culicidae)|journal=The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene|year=2003|volume=69|issue=2|pages=195–9|pmid=13677375}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schaffner|first=F|author2=Raymond, M |author3=Pasteur, N |title=Genetic differentiation of ''Anopheles claviger'' s.s. in France and neighbouring countries|journal=Medical and Veterinary Entomology|year=2000|volume=14|issue=3|pages=264–71|pmid=11016433|doi=10.1046/j.1365-2915.2000.00232.x}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Schaffner|first=F|author2=Marquine, M |author3=Pasteur, N |author4= Raymond, M |title=Genetic differentiation of ''Anopheles claviger'' s.s. in Europe|journal=Journal of Medical Entomology|year=2003|volume=40|issue=6|pages=865–75|pmid=14765664 |doi=10.1603/0022-2585-40.6.865}}</ref>
==Distribution==
''Anopheles claviger'' is found throughout Palearctic ecozone including Afghanistan, Albania, Armenia, Austria, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Belgium, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iran, Iraq, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Jordan, Kyrgyzstan, Latvia, Lebanon, Lithuania, Moldova, Netherlands, Norway, Pakistan, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Syria, Tajikistan, Turkey, Turkmenistan, Ukraine, United Kingdom, Uzbekistan, Serbia and Montenegro,<ref name="WRBU"/> extending to Middle East, China and Siberia.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anopheles claviger (Meigen 1804)|url=http://www.eutaxa.com/Anopheles%20claviger.htm|work=eutaxa|accessdate=26 April 2014}}</ref> Member of the species complex ''An. petragnani'' is found only in western Mediterranean including France and Spain, up to Turkey,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kasap|first=M|title=Seasonal variation in populations of ''Anopheles maculipennis'', ''Anopheles claviger'' and ''Culex pipiens'' in Turkey|journal=Journal of the American Mosquito Control Association|year=1986|volume=2|issue=4|pages=478–81|pmid=3507525}}</ref> and absent from beyond.<ref name=kampen/>
==Description==
Female ''An. claviger'' is distinguished from other related species from its brownish colour and dark palps. It is also generally larger than others. The proboscis is dark-brown while the antennae are brown. The scales on the wings are dark, evenly distributed without any dark spot. The thorax and abdomen are brown with lighter colour at the posterior end. ''An. petragnani'' are generally darker than typical ''An. claviger''. Males are basically similar but have complex arrangements of setae with dinstinct gonostyle.<ref name=kaiser/>
==Biology==
''An. claviger'' adults are most abundant in May and September during which maximum biting on humans takes place. The larval forms are most abundant during cold season from October to the next April. Larvae are generally found in cool and clean water. In the Mediterranean region they are commonly found in wells and water containers (very common in cisterns). In cold area the larvae [[hibernate]] during winter but in warmer climate, they do not hibernate although development is slow. Larvae of ''An. petragnani'' are slightly different in that they can tolerate higher water temperature. Therefore they can be found during summer under rockholes, ditches, canals and river banks. Mature larvae develop in the eggs 5 to 7 days after [[oviposition]]. Most eggs hatch within the next three days, but some may take up to one month. Females of the second generation (September) generally lay fewer eggs than those of the first generation (May). Egg maturation requires blood meal and about six days are required for blood digestion.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Service|first=M. W.|title=The biology of ''Anopheles claviger'' (Mg.) (Dipt., Culicidae) in southern England|journal=Bulletin of Entomological Research|year=2009|volume=63|issue=02|pages=347|doi=10.1017/S0007485300039110}}</ref> Females attack human soon after they mate with males. They bite during broad daylight.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gramiccia|first=G|title=''Anopheles claviger'' in the Middle East|journal=Bulletin of the World Health Organization|year=1956|volume=15|issue=3-5|pages=816–21|pmid=13404456|pmc=2538294}}</ref> Females hardly live inside houses so that biting occurs in open places. Unlike other anopheline mosquitoes which deposit their eggs directly on the water surface, female ''An. claviger'' lays eggs just above the water level but still in the wet area. They are zoophillic in that they bite mostly of large mammals including humans. There is no report ''An. petragnani'' in transmission of human malaria, indicating that they are exclusively zoophillic.<ref name=kaiser/>
==Scientific importance==
''An. claviger'' was experimentally used to discover the transmission of human malarial parasite ''P. falciparum'', along with the fact that only female anophelines can transmit malaria. Before 1898 it was not known how malaria was transmitted. The Italian biologist Giovanni Battista Grassi started investigating different mosquito species in the early 1898 on the basis of [[mosquito-malaria theory]]. He suspected that only certain species were involved in transmission of malaria. In September Battista reported the presence of malarial parasite in ''An. claviger'' indicating it as malaria vector. Battista performed human experimentation on Abele Sola, who had been a patient for six years in the Hospital of the Holy Spirit ([[Ospedale di Santo Spirito in Sassia]]) in Rome. With mutual consent Sola was bitten by malaria-infected mosquitoes for ten nights, and after few weeks he was down with tertian malaria. Battista and his colleagues [[Amico Bignami]], [[Giuseppe Bastianelli]] and [[Ettore Marchiafava]] continued to demonstrate the same experiments in other patients and were always successful. In November they found the parasites on the gut wall of the infected mosquitoes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Grove|first=David|title=Tapeworms, Lice and Prions : a Compendium of Unpleasant Infections|year=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press, Inc.|location=Oxford, UK|isbn=978-0-19-964102-4|pages=131–132|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FHo9AgAAQBAJ&dq=grassi+anopheles+claviger&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref> ''P. falciparum''-carrying mosquito was no doubt the causative vector of malaria. They formally announced the discovery at the session of the [[Accademia dei Lincei]] on 4 December 1898.<ref name=capanna/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Baccetti|first=B|title=History of the early dipteran systematics in Italy: from Lyncei to Battista Grassi|journal=Parassitologia|year=2008|volume=50|issue=3-4|pages=167–72|pmid=20055226}}</ref> This experiment further established that ''An. claviger'' is the sole mosquito species responsible for human malaria in Italy, and other European countries. (In other parts of the world other species of ''Anopheles'' are responsible.) In addition the discovery laid the foundation for prevention of malaria by vector control of mosquitoes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Dobson|first=MJ|title=The malariology centenary|journal=Parassitologia|year=1999|volume=41|issue=1-3|pages=21–32|pmid=10697830}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Lehrer|first=Steven|title=Explorers of the Body : Dramatic Breakthroughs in Medicine from Ancient Times to Modern Science|year=2006|publisher=iUniverse|location=Lincoln, US|isbn=9780595407316|pages=272–273|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cIZpyNvjvdcC&pg|edition=2nd}}</ref>
