The '''Sagamihara stabbings''' were committed on 26 July 2016 in [[Midori-ku, Sagamihara|Midori Ward]], [[Sagamihara]], [[Kanagawa Prefecture|Kanagawa]], [[Japan]]. Nineteen people were killed and twenty-six others were injured, thirteen severely, at a [[residential care|care home]] for disabled people.<ref name="cnn"/><ref name="rt">{{cite web|title=19 killed, 45 injured as knife-wielding man goes on rampage at medical facility near Tokyo|url=https://www.rt.com/news/353242-tokyo-stabbing-killed-rampage/|publisher=RT|location=Russia|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref> The suspect was a 26-year-old man, identified as {{nihongo|Satoshi Uematsu|植松 聖|Uematsu Satoshi}}, a former employee of the care facility.<ref name=Guardian.KnifeAttack/> Uematsu surrendered at a nearby police station with a bag of knives and was subsequently arrested.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-36890655|title=Japan Sagamihara knife attack: At least 19 dead, reports say|publisher=BBC News|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="rt" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/d6b5f7b2e68843f8bf6b1623383a2923|title=At least 15 killed, dozens injured in knifing near Tokyo|agency=Associated Press|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref> The attack was described as one of the [[List of massacres in Japan|worst crimes]] committed on Japanese soil in modern history.<ref name=Guardian.KnifeAttack/>
==Location== {{Location map+ | Japan Kanagawa Prefecture |caption = Location of Tsukui Yamayuri En within [[Kanagawa Prefecture]] |width=260px | places = {{Location map~ |Japan Kanagawa Prefecture | lat_deg=35 |lat_min=36 |lat_sec =49 |lon_deg=139 |lon_min=12 | lon_sec=47 |label=Tsukui Yamayuri En |position=bottom}} {{Location map~ |Japan Kanagawa Prefecture | lat_deg =35 | lat_min = 34|lat_sec=53 | lon_deg = 139 | lon_min = 22 |lon_sec=14 |label=[[Sagamihara Station]] |mark=Blue pog.svg |position=top}} {{Location map~ |Japan Kanagawa Prefecture | lat_deg =35 | lat_min = 27|lat_sec=56 | lon_deg = 139 | lon_min = 37 |lon_sec=22 |label=[[Yokohama Station]] |mark=Blue pog.svg |position=top}} {{Location map~ |Japan Kanagawa Prefecture | lat_deg =35 | lat_min = 15|lat_sec=23 | lon_deg = 139 | lon_min = 09 |lon_sec=18 |label=[[Odawara Station]] |mark=Blue pog.svg |position=top}} }}
{{nihongo|Tsukui Lily Garden|津久井やまゆり園|Tsukui Yamayuri En}} is a residential care center run by {{nihongo|Kanagawa Kyodokai|社会福祉法人かながわ共同会|Shakai Fukushi Hōjin Kanagawa Kyōdōkai}}, a social welfare organization.<ref name="staffersJT">{{cite news|title=Care facility staffers express concern over security following Kanagawa stabbing|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/07/26/national/crime-legal/care-facility-staffers-express-concern-security-following-kanagawa-stabbing/#.V5fjkqLKvEs|publisher=The Japan Times|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref> Established by the local government, the facility was built in a {{convert|30,890|sqm|acre}} area of woodland on the bank of the [[Sagami River]].<ref name=Reuters.Feared>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-attack-idUSKCN1052D0|title=Nineteen feared dead after knife attack in Japan: media reports|date=25 July 2016|agency=Reuters|accessdate=25 July 2016|first1=William|last1=Mallard|first2=Eric|last2=Beech|first3=Jon|last3=Herskovitz}}</ref><ref name=Guardian.Attack>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2016/jul/25/japan-knife-attack-live-updates|title=Japan attack: suspect turns himself in after 19 killed in stabbing – live|work=The Guardian|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016|first=Nicky|last=Woolf}}</ref> As of the end of April, the facility housed 149 residents between the ages of 19 and 75, all of whom had an [[intellectual disability]] but many with various [[Physical disability|physical disabilities]] as well. Some are capable of engaging in physical activities outdoors, while others are bedridden.<ref name=Guardian.KnifeAttack/><ref name=Guardian.Attack/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Japan-Update/Stabbing-spree-in-Japan-leaves-at-least-19-dead|title=Stabbing spree in Japan leaves at least 19 dead|work=Nikkei Asian Review|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref><ref name="fifield19">{{cite news|last1=Fifield|first1=Anna|title=19 people reported dead in knife attack in Japan|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/at-least-15-people-reported-dead-in-knife-attack-in-japan/2016/07/25/b0052b71-2c28-4de2-bd0d-577ccbca6586_story.html|publisher=The Washington Post|date=25 July 2016}}</ref> The facility is located in a remote location about {{convert|2|km|mi}} from [[Sagamiko Station]] on the [[Chūō Main Line]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.jp/2016/07/25/tsukui-yamayurien_n_11190408.html|title=「津久井やまゆり園」とは？ 元職員が入所者を刺し19人死亡|trans-title=The "Tsukui lily garden"? 19 deaths original staff stabbed residents|work=Huffington Post Japan|date=25 June 2016|accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref>
==Attack== At about 02:10, [[#Suspect|Satoshi Uematsu]] allegedly used a hammer to break into the care center through a glass window on the first floor. He tied up a staff member, took their keys, and then went from room to room, stabbing the victims in their necks as they slept.<ref name=Guardian.KnifeAttack>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/25/tokyo-knife-attack-stabbing-sagamihara|title=Japan knife attack: 19 killed and dozens wounded in stabbing|work=The Guardian|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016|first=Justin|last=McCurry}}</ref><ref name=NationalPost.Arrested>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/world/nineteen-dead-and-20-injured-in-knife-attack-outside-tokyo-reports|title=Suspect arrested after knife attack outside Tokyo leaves at least 15 dead and 26 injured|work=National Post|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016|first=Anna|last=Fifield}}</ref> Police were called to the care center by staff members at around 02:30 local time, reporting a man with a knife breaking into the building. However, Uematsu left the premises before being apprehended; he was recorded leaving the facility at 02:50 in security camera footage.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/1501815/former-employee-shouting-i-want-to-get-rid-of-the-disabled-kills-19-and-injures-45-at-care-home-near-tokyo-months-after-warning-parliament-he-would-carry-out-the-massacre/ |title=JAPAN KNIFE RAMPAGE First picture of ex-employee who killed 19 and injured 45 at care home |work=The Sun |first=Scarlet |last=Howes |date=25 June 2016 |accessdate=29 July 2016}}</ref>
Armed police entered the building at around 03:00 where they discovered the crime scene.<ref name=bbc/> Twenty-nine ambulances were sent to the facility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/07/26/national/crime-legal/man-arrested-fatally-stabbing-15-people-wounding-45-kanagawa-facility-disabled-nhk/|title=Man arrested after killing 15 and wounding 45 in knife attack at Kanagawa care facility|work=Japan Times|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref> The suspect turned himself in at the Tsukui Police Station two hours after the incident with a bag containing kitchen knives and other bloodstained sharp tools.<ref name="rt" /><ref name="Guardian.Attack" /> A knife was reportedly found in his car outside the police station.<ref name=NationalPost.Arrested/>
Uematsu allegedly killed ten women and nine men aged between 18 and 70<ref name="Guardian.KnifeAttack"/> and injured 26 more, 13 severely.<ref name="cnn"/><ref name="rt" /><ref name=Reuters.Feared/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/26/world/asia/knife-japan-stabbing-sagamihara.html|title=At Least 15 Are Killed in Knife Attack Near Tokyo|date=25 July 2016|work=The New York Times|accessdate=25 July 2016|first=Motoko|last=Rich}}</ref><ref name="WaPost">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/at-least-15-people-reported-dead-in-knife-attack-in-japan/2016/07/25/b0052b71-2c28-4de2-bd0d-577ccbca6586_story.html|title=At least 15 people reported dead in knife attack in Japan|work=The Washington Post|date=25 July 2016|accessdate=25 July 2016}}</ref>
==Suspect== '''{{Nihongo|Satoshi Uematsu|植松 聖|Uematsu Satoshi}},''' born in 1990, was a 26-year-old male at the time of the incident and used to work at the care home Tsukui Yamayuri En.<ref name="bbc"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2124699-japan-stabbing-attack-15-dead-45-injured-in-sagamihara-kanagawa-prefecture/ |title=Japan Stabbing Attack: 19 Dead, More Than 20 Injured in Sagamihara |website=The Epoch Times |date=25 July 2016 |accessdate=25 July 2016 |first=Jack |last=Phillips}}</ref> His father was an elementary school art teacher, and Uematsu had trained and worked as an elementary school teacher as well. He had lived in his house with his parents, but they moved away at some point and he remained there alone.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ex-employee stabs 19 people to death in Japan care home|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/07/deadly-knife-attack-facility-disabled-japan-160725213035222.html|website=[[Al Jazeera]]|publisher=[[Al Jazeera Media Network]]|accessdate=7 September 2016|date=26 July 2016}}</ref> He resigned from working at the facility in February 2016 after having been employed there for over three years.<ref name="obeWar">{{cite news|first1=Eleanor|last1=Warnock|first2=Mitsuru|last2=Obe|title=Mass Killing in Japan Shocks a Gentle Nation|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/mass-killing-in-japan-shocks-a-gentle-nation-1469533910|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref>
Neighbors expressed surprise that he had allegedly committed the murders; he was described as a friendly, outgoing and good man. However, some reported that his personality had undergone a change at some point during his employment at the facility.<ref name="nytRich"/><ref name="bbcWho"/><ref name="teleConn">{{cite news|last1=Connor|first1=Neil|title=Japan knife attack suspect said 'disabled people should be euthanised,' before killing 19|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/07/26/japan-knife-attacker-said-disabled-people-should-be-euthanised-b/|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=27 July 2016}}</ref>
===Letter and statements=== In February 2016, Uematsu attempted to hand-deliver a letter to [[Tadamori Oshima]], the [[List of Speakers of the House of Representatives of Japan|Speaker of the House of Representatives of Japan]], at Oshima's home in Tokyo but was prevented from doing so by security. He returned the following day and this time left the letter with the security guards.<ref name="nytRich">{{cite news|last1=Rich|first1=Motoko|title=Japan Knife Attack Kills 19 at Center for Disabled|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/26/world/asia/knife-japan-stabbing-sagamihara.html|work=The New York Times|date=25 July 2016}}</ref> Uematsu's letter appealed for the legalization of ending the lives of those with multiple disabilities in cases where it was requested by their guardians, and asked for Oshima's assistance in delivering his message to [[Prime Minister of Japan|Japanese Prime Minister]] [[Shinzo Abe]]. In it, he wrote, "I envision a world where a person with multiple disabilities can be [[involuntary euthanasia|euthanised]], with an agreement from the guardians, when it is difficult for the person to carry out household and social activities."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jul/26/japan-care-home-attack-satoshi-uematsu-horrifying-vision-disabled-people|title=Japan care home attack: picture emerges of modest man with horrifying vision|first=Justin|last=McCurry|date=26 July 2016|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref> He also wrote that the killings of the disabled would be "for the sake of Japan and world peace" as well as to benefit the global economy and prevent [[World War III]].<ref name="bbc"/><ref name="asahiAP">{{cite news|title=Letter by man accused of mass stabbings carried eerie warning|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201607260083.html|agency=Associated Press|work=Asahi Shimbun|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}}{{dl|date=May 2018}}</ref>
After signing his name, the letter proceeded to detail an offer to target two facilities housing the disabled (possibly a reference to the two residential buildings in which he later committed the crime), and went on to appeal for certain conditions in exchange for committing the act. In the first half of the message, Uematsu said he could kill 460 people; however, in the second half, the number he gave was 260. He added that staff would be tied up to keep them from interfering but that they would not be harmed, the act would be swift, and that afterwards he would turn himself in. At the end of the latter half of the letter, he signed his name again, this time with his address, telephone number, and the name of his employer.<ref name="asahiAP"/>
At some point, the letter was handed over to Tokyo police, who contacted the police in Sagamihara. During this time frame, Uematsu posted to his [[Twitter]] account that he expected he might be arrested.<ref name="bbcWho">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-36891375 | title=Japan knife attack: Who is suspect Satoshi Uematsu? | publisher=BBC | date=26 July 2016 | accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref> He had previously posted tweets about Japan being ravaged by [[radiation poisoning]] and [[AIDS in Japan|AIDS]].<ref name="rtLiesHa">{{cite news|first1=Elaine|last1=Lies|first2=Kwiyeon|last2=Ha|title=Shock as peaceful Japanese town wakes to 'unthinkable' disabled center horror|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-japan-attack-scene-idUSKCN1060I9|agency=Reuters|date=26 July 2016|accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref>
Later that month, after his letter was brought to the attention of Sagamihara's authorities, he was arrested, detained, questioned, and then involuntarily committed to a psychiatric hospital for two weeks.<ref name="remorseJT">{{cite news|title=Suspect in Sagamihara care facility mass murder says he has ‘no remorse’|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2016/07/27/national/crime-legal/suspect-sagamihara-care-facility-mass-murder-says-no-remorse/#.V5iSHKLKvEt|publisher=The Japan Times|date=27 July 2016}}</ref> However, he was released on 2 March after doctors deemed that he was not a threat.<ref name="Guardian.Attack" /><ref name="sydmorn">{{cite news|title=Tokyo knifeman kills nearly two dozen|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/tokyo-knifeman-kills-more-than-a-dozen-reports-20160725-gqdm48.html|accessdate=26 July 2016|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|agency=Associated Press|date=26 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20160726/p2a/00m/0na/005000c |title=Neighbors describe alleged stabber at facility for disabled as 'cheerful' |language=ja |publisher=The Mainichi |date=26 July 2016 |accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0003105111 |title=Sagamihara knife attack / Neighbors, families express fear, shock |publisher=The Japan News |date=26 July 2016 |accessdate=26 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Pascaline|first1=Mary|title=Japan Knife Attack: Several Dead, Scores Injured At Care Center In West Tokyo|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/japan-knife-attack-several-dead-scores-injured-care-center-west-tokyo-2394791|accessdate=26 July 2016|work=International Business Times|date=26 July 2016}}</ref>
In his letter and in statements made after turning himself in, Uematsu explained that he was "saving from unhappiness" both the severely disabled and those who he believed were burdened with maintaining their lives.<ref name="asahiAP"/><ref name="remorseJT"/>
===Legal proceedings=== On 20 February 2017, Uematsu was found mentally competent to stand trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/02/21/national/crime-legal/accused-killer-19-sagamihara-facility-deemed-fit-stand-trial-sources/|title=Accused killer of 19 at Sagamihara facility deemed fit to stand trial: sources|date=21 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=26 July 2018|via=Japan Times Online}}</ref> On 24 February, Uematsu was charged with 19 counts of murder, 24 counts of attempted murder, two counts of illegal confinement causing injury, three counts of illegal confinement, one count of unlawful entry, and one count of violating the swords and firearms control law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201702240075.html|title=Suspect deemed fit to stand trial, indicted on 19 murder charges：The Asahi Shimbun|publisher=|accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
==Reactions== [[Yoshihide Suga]], the Japanese [[Chief Cabinet Secretary]], acknowledged that the attack was "a very heart-wrenching and shocking incident in which many innocent people became victims".<ref name="bbc"/><ref name=Reuters.Feared/> He also said that the [[Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare]] would investigate ways to prevent a similar incident from occurring again.<ref name="cnn"/>
A number of Japanese news outlets ran [[editorial]]s calling the stabbings a [[disability hate crime|hate crime]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.okinawatimes.co.jp/articles/-/49918 | title=社説[障がい者施設殺傷]兆候は幾つも出ていた | work=Okinawa Times | date=27 July 2016 | accessdate=2 August 2016}} {{Ja icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://mainichi.jp/articles/20160727/ddm/010/040/038000c | title=相模原の障害者施設殺傷 - 識者の見方 | work=[[Mainichi Shimbun]] | date=27 July 2016 | accessdate=2 August 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Ja icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sankei.com/affairs/news/160802/afr1608020004-n1.html | title=【相模原１９人刺殺】 憎悪と計画性、浮かぶ異様さ | work=[[Sankei Shimbun]] | date=2 August 2016 | accessdate=2 August 2016}} {{Ja icon}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://mainichi.jp/articles/20160802/org/00m/040/005000c | title=Ｌｉｓｔｅｎｉｎｇ ＜記者の目＞相模原殺傷事件＝須藤孝（政治部） | work=[[Mainichi Shimbun]] | date=2 August 2016 | accessdate=2 August 2016}} {{Ja icon}}</ref> By September 2016, little information had been released about the victims of the attack. Reuters wrote that this was due to Japanese culture and [[social stigma|stigma]] being less accepting of physically and cognitively impaired persons.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ha|first1=Kwiyeon|last2=Sieg|first2=Linda|title=FEATURE: Japan confronts disability stigma after attack|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/japan-disabled-idUSL3N1BS0AV|accessdate=17 September 2016|work=Taipei Times|agency=Reuters|date=16 September 2016|archiveurl=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2016/09/17/2003655318|archivedate=17 September 2016}}</ref>
On 13 September 2016, the governor of [[Kanagawa Prefecture]], [[Yuji Kuroiwa]], said the facility would be rebuilt.<ref>[http://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/article/kanagawa/list/201609/CK2016091302000185.html やまゆり園建て替えへ 再生に向け本格始動] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914155811/http://www.tokyo-np.co.jp/article/kanagawa/list/201609/CK2016091302000185.html |date=14 September 2016 }}</ref>

The concept of the soft path was first used for energy resource management and was developed by [[Amory Lovins]] shortly after the shock of the [[1973 energy crisis]] in the United States.<ref>"Energy Strategy: The Road Not Taken?" published in Foreign Affairs, in October 1976</ref> This concept has now been refined and applied to water, most notably by water expert [[Peter Gleick]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pacinst.org/topics/water_and_sustainability/soft_path/nature_07252002.pdf|title=P.H. Gleick, 2002. Nature, Volume 418, pg. 373, July 25, 2002|publisher=}}</ref> and David Brooks.<ref>Making the Most of the Water We Have: The Soft Path Approach to Water Management, Edited By David B. Brooks, Oliver M. Brandes and Stephen Gurman, Earthscan, 2009</ref> The soft path is often framed as a more integrated and effective alternative to supply-side water resource management. Supply-side water management focuses on meeting demands for water through centralized, large-scale physical infrastructure, and centralized water management systems. In the 20th century, this approach focused on constructing bigger dams and drilling deeper wells to access more water to meet projected demands of consumers. More recently, a focus on demand-side management has emerged in regions where water supply is increasingly constrained (see, for example, [[Peak water]]), and it focuses on managing demand and making current practices more efficient. The soft path integrates both supply and demand concepts but in a broader context by recognizing that water is a means to satisfy demands for goods and services and asking how much water, of what qualities, is actually required to satisfy those demands efficiently and sustainably.<ref>Page 4. The Soft Path for Water in a Nutshell. 2005. Oliver M Brandes and David B Brooks. Friends of the Earth and POLIS Project on Ecological Governance. University of Victoria, Victoria, BC.</ref> Soft path water planning also requires broader institutional approaches to water management including the application of smart economics, the potential for distributed rather than centralized water systems, and more democratic participation in water policy decisions.<ref>G. Wolff and P.H. Gleick, "The Soft Path for Water" in The World's Water 2002-2003 (Island Press, Washington D.C., pp. 1-32.[http://www.pacinst.org/publications/worlds_water/worlds_water_2002_chapter1.pdf]</ref> Others have described the soft path as "unleashing the full potential of demand-side management.",<ref>[Quote]{{cite web |url=http://www.poliswaterproject.org/softpath |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120907002645/http://www.poliswaterproject.org/softpath |archivedate=2012-09-07 |df= }} [Oliver M Brandes water expert]http://www.cbc.ca/blueprintalberta/experts/oliver-brandes.html</ref><ref>Page 4. Thinking Beyond Pipes and Pumps. (2006) Oliver M Brandes, Tony Maas and Ellen Reynolds. POLIS Project on Ecological Governance. University of Victoria, Victoria, BC.</ref>
==Publications== * [http://www.poliswaterproject.org/publication/284 The Soft Path for Water in a Nutshell. 2005. Oliver M Brandes and David B Brooks. Friends of the Earth and POLIS Project on Ecological Governance. University of Victoria, Victoria, BC.] * [http://www.pacinst.org/publications/worlds_water/worlds_water_2002_chapter1.pdf G. Wolff and P.H. Gleick, "The Soft Path for Water" in The World's Water 2002-2003 (Island Press, Washington D.C., pp. 1-32.] * [http://www.pacinst.org/topics/water_and_sustainability/soft_path/science_112003.pdf P.H. Gleick, 2003. ''Science'', Volume 302, November 28, 2003, pp. 1524-1528.] * [http://www.pacinst.org/topics/water_and_sustainability/soft_path/nature_07252002.pdf P.H. Gleick, 2002. Nature, Volume 418, pg. 373, July 25, 2002.] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080513184013/http://www.iisd.org/natres/water/soft_paths.asp Manitoba Water Soft Path 2006.] * The Energy Controversy: Soft Path Questions and Answers (1979) {{ISBN|978-0-913890-22-6}} * [http://www.poliswaterproject.org/sites/default/files/oliver_casestudy.pdf A New Path to Water Sustainability for the Town of Oliver, BC - Soft Path Case Study by Oliver M Brandes Tony Maas Adam Mjolsness Ellen Reynolds. Uvic Printers. Feb 2008.]

'''The Aversion Project''' was a [[medical torture]] program in [[South Africa]] led by Dr. [[Aubrey Levin]]<ref name=":1" /> during [[apartheid]]. The project identified gay soldiers as [[conscripts]] who used drugs in the [[South African Defence Force]]s (SADF). Victims were forced to submit to "curing" their [[homosexuality]]<ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thegully.com/essays/africa/000825sexchange.html |title=Africa | Apartheid Military Forced Gay Troops Into Sex-Change Operations |publisher=The Gully |date=2000-08-25 |accessdate=2013-02-04}}</ref> because the SADF considered homosexuality to be "subversive" and those who were homosexual were subject to punishment.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = Treatment of homosexuality during apartheid|url = http://www.bmj.com/content/329/7480/1415|journal = BMJ|date = 2004-12-16|issn = 0959-8138|pmc = 535952|pmid = 15604160|pages = 1415–1416|volume = 329|issue = 7480|doi = 10.1136/bmj.329.7480.1415|first = Robert M.|last = Kaplan}}</ref> The approach taken by the SADF to treating the homosexual and transsexual patients were done with extremely old knowledge that can be taken back to the ideologies of Havelock Ellis.<ref name=":5" /> The requirement for homosexuals going through gender reassignment surgery is to have extensive assessment and a period of supervision for two years.<ref name=":5" /> In 1995 the Medical Association of South Africa issued a public apology for past wrongdoings.
== History ==
During the [[Apartheid]] Era in South Africa there existed a dual policy on homosexuality in the South African military. This dual policy consisted of two major components which prohibited permanent members of the force from being homosexual, while permitting homosexuality amongst conscripts. The dual policy was adopted because officials believed that banning homosexuality from the military completely would give a specific group of individuals – young, white South African men – a convenient way to avoid serving in the military. Thus, the dual policy was adopted and enforced; however, with toleration of homosexuality came forced 'therapy,' such as compulsion shock therapy, castration, and other forms of 'therapy' which were said to significantly violate basic human rights.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Belkin|first=Aaron|last2=Canaday|first2=Margot|year=2010|title=Assessing the Integration of Gays and Lesbians into the South African National Defence Force|url=|journal=Scientia Militaria: South African Journal of Military Studies|volume=38.2|pages=1–21|via=|doi=10.5787/38-2-87}}</ref> Between 1971 and 1989, victims were submitted to [[chemical castration]] and [[Electroconvulsive therapy|electric shock treatment]] meant to cure them of their homosexuality.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2000/jul/29/chrismcgreal|title = Gays Tell of Mutilation by Apartheid Army|last = McGreal|first = Chris|date = 28 July 2000|work = The Guardian|access-date = 23 August 2015|via = }}</ref> This trend was heavily supported by psychiatrists with the idea that homosexuals were mentally ill, which was stated in the American Psychiatric Associations "Diagnostic and Statistic Manual of Mental Disorders".<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Kaplan|first=Robert|year=2004|title=Treatment of Homosexuality During Apartheid|jstor=25469630|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=329|pages=1415–1416|doi=10.1136/bmj.329.7480.1415}}</ref> Conscripts with this proclaimed 'mental illness' were treated significantly different than other members of the military. They were not given military leadership positions and they were not entrusted with sensitive information.<ref name=":6" /> During the course of the shock therapy treatment electrodes were strapped to the upper arm with wires, then run through a dial calibrated from 1 to 10, varying the current. Homosexual soldiers were shown black and white pictures of a naked man and were encouraged to fantasize, at which a point the person-in-charge would administer a shock if the soldiers showed any form of sexual response and voltage was increased throughout the treatment if the soldiers continued to exhibit sexual responses. The patient would then be shown a colored picture of a woman, which was supposed to stimulate arousal, however, more often than not, this failed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kaplan|first=Robert|year=2001|title=THE AVERSION PROJECT-PSYCHIATRIC ABUSES IN THE SOUTH AFRICAN DEFENCE FORCE DURING THE APARTHEID ERA|url= https://aubreylevinvictims.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/the-aversion-project-psychiatric-abuses-in-sadf-during-the-apartheid-1_page_1.jpg |journal=Health and Human Rights|volume=91|pages=1–2|via=SAMJ Forum}}</ref> As a result of these failures, there is also evidence that [[Sex reassignment surgery|sexual realignment procedures]] took place on the individuals who were unable to be 'cured.' <ref name=":6" /> Because there is no scientific evidence to prove that 'therapies' have the ability to alter ones sexuality, these tortures reached their peak during the 1970s, where therapy for homosexual soldiers was no longer supported by the field of mental health.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=De Gruchy J|first=Jeanelle|last2=Lewin|first2=Simon|year=2001|title=Ethics that Exclude: The Role of Ethics Committees in Lesbian and Gay Health Research in South Africa|url=|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=91|pages=865–868|via=|doi=10.2105/ajph.91.6.865|pmc=1446457}}</ref> Consequently, the definition of homosexuals as mentally ill was removed from the [[American Psychiatric Association]]s manual in 1973, and the treatment was left behind.<ref name=":3" />
== The Aversion Research Project == A team of individuals: academic researchers and activists on behalf of the [[Gay]] community came together in order to obtain more information about the treatment of homosexual military personnel during the Apartheid Era. This was a research project based on qualitative methodology that helped to further examine why homosexuality was considered to be unusual behavior at that time. Various homosexual individuals – who were targets of the conversion therapy – along with the families and friends of these individuals were interviewed in order to obtain in-depth, first hand, experiences of those directly impacted. Prior to following through with the project, the researchers had to be approved by a research committee. However, the research committee had an issue with researchers using the word ''abuse'' as a way of describing what happened to homosexual military personnel. The research committee believed that considering the conversion 'therapy' to be abuse was only an assumption, it was not supported by factual evidence. Therefore, the term ''abuse'', when used in the research project, had to be supported with factual evidence. Additionally, the researchers considered the actions of psychologists initiating this conversion shock therapy as a human rights violation. The research ethics committee, on the other hand, did not agree. This raised concerns about the research project because the committee did not want this to be an investigation into the practices of medical officials involved in the military. Furthermore, the committee questioned the sampling methods of the researchers. Because researchers would be accepting volunteers, they found that the sampling method used would not be representative of the experience as a whole.<ref name=":7" />
== Medical abuse of homosexuals in South Africa == The medical abuse of patients in South Africa can be seen in various situations, aside from just the conversion therapy. To protect the health of your citizens includes treating them all with the same respect and equality. A doctors first priority should be working towards finding a solution for the medical problem the patient presents them with. However, different than many other countries, South Africa was still very religiously traditional and divided racially amongst its citizens. This led to the connection between being homophobic and engaging in a violation of human rights. Gay patients health issues were neglected and stereotyped. Doctors showed clear discrimination against gay patients when they paid less attention to fulfilling their needs because of the association of HIV/AIDS with homosexual men. This led to inadequate health care, and additional abuse from those who value the medical opinion of doctors.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Jones|first=Tiffany|year=2008|title=Averting White Male (Ab)normality: Psychiatric Representations and Treatment of Homosexuality in 1960's South Africa|jstor=40283145|journal=Journal of Southern African Studies.|volume=34|pages=168}}</ref> One can also attribute the abuse of homosexuals to economic and social problems that South Africa may have been facing during that time. This can be explained by some as the need to regain social control. The racial divide in South Africa put anyone other than the white man outside of the norm. According to Sander Gilman, "the worldwide concept of pervasion is the basic quality ascribed to the other. in turn blacks, women, and those deemed sexually deviant were seen as fundamentally disordered and were institutionalized in numbers far higher than straight white men"<ref name=":4" /> This bothering can be used to explain why whites in South Africa felt so strongly about homosexuality, and finding a way to get rid of it.
== Aubrey Levin == [[Aubrey Levin]] was the primary leader of the project against homosexual military personnel. He argued that the same type of procedures could cure other groups. These included [[Drug of abuse|drug]] addicts and the disturbed (those who did not want to serve in the apartheid military). He started the project and ran Ward 22 at 1 Military Hospital, in [[Voortrekkerhoogte]], which is where majority of the patients were treated. He was one of 24 other doctors that were warned by the truth and reconciliation commission that what they were doing was a violation of human rights, and they risked being labeled as perpetrators of human rights abuses.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=https://aubreylevinvictims.files.wordpress.com/2013/02/the-aversion-project-psychiatric-abuses-in-sadf-during-the-apartheid-1_page_2.jpg|title=The Aversion Project Psychiatric Abuses in the South African Defense Force During the Apartheid Era|last=Kaplan|first=Robert|date=March 2001|work=|access-date=|via=World Press}}</ref> Levin has admitted to the abuse claiming that all patients were "volunteers".<ref name=":4" /> Since then, Levin has been accused of many more instances of medical foul practice, targeting many other men (not only those who identified as homosexual). He was sentenced in a five-year prison sentence on April 23, 2014, which is where he currently resides awaiting release.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewalrus.ca/doctor-shock/|title=Dr. Shock|last=Poplack|first=Richard|date=|work=Dr. Shock|access-date=2017-02-28|language=en-CA}}</ref>
== Post-Project == After the conversion therapy was noticeably failing, staff came up with an alternative. As a result, whenever treatments would not work, they put patients through a [[sex change operation]]. This included being put through surgery and being given a new identity.<ref name=":3" /> Patients would then be discharged from the military, and advised to cut themselves off from family and friends. As many as 900 homosexuals, mostly 16–24 year-olds who had been [[Draft (conscription)|drafted]], were surgically turned into women and given birth certificates to fit their modified anatomy. This surgery was done in military hospitals and a high rate of patients died during surgery. Additionally, the reassignments were often incomplete, leaving patients with a halfway finished procedures.<ref name=":2" /> After being discharged there were no follow-up appointments to finish the surgeries or check on their progress mentally and physically. In order to stay on track with their gender reassignment, patients needed an expensive supply of hormones, but they typically lacked the means to pay for these hormones to maintain their new identities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alternet.org/print/10-most-evil-medical-experiments-conducted-history | title=10 of the Most Evil Medical Experiments Conducted in History|publisher=Alternet.org|accessdate=2015-08-22}}</ref> When converting from one sex to another, there is a lengthy process that accompanies the success; individuals must be prepared both mentally and physically for the drastic changes that are going to take place. Without this preparation, patients also faced depression leading to many of these patients to committing suicide.<ref name=":2" />

'''The Practice PLC''' is one of the largest providers of [[Primary Care]] in the English NHS.
The Practice was established in 2004 - then called Practice Networks - by Dr Jeremy Rose and Dr Ajit Kadirgamar in [[Amersham]]. It now runs over 50 GP surgeries and GP-led Health Centres. In February 2014 it had the biggest list of about 174,000 registered patients of any provider in England.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dominance of small GP practices undermines push for extended providers|url=http://www.hsj.co.uk/news/primary-care/dominance-of-small-gp-practices-undermines-push-for-extended-providers/5068088.article#.U8KzGfldUk4|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=19 February 2014}}</ref>
In February 2012 the company closed down the Camden Road Surgery – a long-standing GP practice previously taken over by US health company [[UnitedHealth]] in 2008 - less than a year after taking over the contract because the surgery's landlord refused an extension for the premises lease beyond April 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Private firm closes flagship GP practice in north London|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/news/private-firm-closes-flagship-gp-practice-in-north-london/13395610.article#.U8K1MPldUk4|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=Pulse|date=8 February 2012}}</ref> Camden Road was one of six practices taken over from [[UnitedHealth]] when the American firm decided to refocus its UK business to concentrate solely on commissioning support, and exploit the opportunities presented by the Government's NHS reforms.<ref>{{cite news|title=UnitedHealth quits primary care and sells off surgeries to The Practice|url=http://www.pulsetoday.co.uk/unitedhealth-quits-primary-care-and-sells-off-surgeries-to-the-practice/12199561.article#.U8K2PfldUk4|accessdate=13 July 2014|publisher=Pulse|date=20 April 2011}}</ref>
In February 2018 its practices had a registered population of more than 200,000. Since 2016 it has been majority owned by the [[Centene Corporation]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Major private GP provider loses top executives|url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/7021690.article?|accessdate=2 April 2018|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=15 February 2018}}</ref> In 2016 it set up TPG Complex Care, which is focused on care at home for patients with complex needs. In March 2016 it had 517 staff - 188 clinical and 331 in administration.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Practice Group Ltd|url=http://www.nhsforsale.info/private-providers/the-practice-plc.html|accessdate=2 April 2018|publisher=NHS For Sale|date=2017}}</ref> It ran five surgeries in Brighton but gave them up in 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fresh start for Brighton family doctors’ surgery|url=http://www.brightonandhovenews.org/2018/03/10/fresh-start-for-brighton-family-doctors-surgery/|accessdate=2 April 2018|publisher=Brighton and Hove News|date=10 March 2018}}</ref>

'''''Van Wyk v Lewis'''''<ref>1924 AD 438.</ref> is an important case in South African law, particularly in the area of delict and on the question of negligence.
== Facts == The defendant, a surgeon, had performed an urgent and difficult abdominal operation upon the plaintiff. The operation took place in a hospital at night, assisted by an anesthetist and a qualified nurse on the hospital staff who acted as theatre sister. At the conclusion of the operation, one of the swabs used by the defendant was overlooked and remained in plaintiff's body, from which it passed after a lapse of twelve months. The evidence showed that:
* in accordance with the usual practice at the hospital, the defendant had relied upon the sister to count and check the swabs used; * at the conclusion of the operation, he made as careful a search as the critical condition of the patient permitted; and that * both he and the sister believed that all the swabs were accounted for before the wound was sewn up.
== Judgment == In an action against the defendant for damages for negligence in failing to remove the swab, the court held that negligence could not be inferred from the mere fact that the accident happened; the onus of establishing negligence lay upon plaintiff. Although the defendant, in performing the operation, was bound to exercise all reasonable care and skill, it was a reasonable and proper practice to leave the duty of checking the swabs to the theatre sister, so the defendant, in following that practice, was not guilty of negligence. Assuming, without deciding, that the sister was negligent in checking the swabs, the court held that the defendant was not liable for the result of such negligence.
The decision of the Queenstown Circuit Local Division, in ''Van Wyk v Lewis'', was thus confirmed.
